ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is a great chance to analyze some brilliant literature, and to connect fiction with theory! Discussions are very thoughtful, and Prof. Habchi is engaging, an expert, and great at explaining highly academic/theoretical discourses around colonialism and diaspora in accessible ways.

This is a fantastic course thats gives you the opportunity to engage with diasporic literature from the Caribbean. Professors Habchi and Carby really pushed us to understand what diaspora even means and what it means in relation to gender, sexuality, and race.
greater understanding of diaspora, colonialism, and academic lens with which to look at ER&M
It was great. I gained great insight into the region of the Caribbean, especially through lenses previously unfamiliar to me.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The literature is amazing and I will miss our class discussions! The paper prompts give you a lot of freedom to research/write about what you would like, and Prof. Habchi is very open to meeting and giving advice/feedback. The syllabus begins with three weeks of pretty in-depth theory (Sylvia Wynter's writing can be particularly hard to untangle), before getting into the literature. I think this is an intentional choice to have that grounding in theory, but I might suggest restructuring it so the theory weeks are evenly interspersed between, or alternating with, the literature weeks.
1 novel a week is quick, so tradeoffs have to be made - workload is very manageable and professor habchi is REALLY supportive
This course was really really good. The once a week structure was interesting, and allowed for a daily depth, although the consistency was less than ideal.

Strengths: 
- Prof Habchi teaches the subject well and clearly knows a lot about the books themselves
- Lots of space for open discussion

Weaknesses: 
- Book club seminar style makes it hard to focus learning on specific concepts

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES, absolutely take it! Great books, and whether or not your academic focus is on the Caribbean, it is such an important site from which to understand colonialism, diaspora, enslavement, racialization, and resistance. A lot of content on patriarchy/gender/queerness as well if you are interested in this. The only reason not to take it is if you do not feel like reading a book a week. I imagine that the course tends to attract people who are interested in thoughtful, collaborative discussion, and Prof. Habchi is great.

If you are interested in diasporic studiesno matter how much you know about it, because I knew nothingand are able to commit to reading about a novel a week, then yes! If you don't think you'll have time to do the majority of the readings, I might not suggest the course because I think you will get a lot less out of it. (Class discussions are grounded in the literary texts, and in connecting them to the theory that we read at the beginning of the semester.) However, the books are WONDERFUL and there isn't an insane amount of work for the course beyond reading, so doing the reading is WORTH IT!
yes!! any class w prof. habchi
I would, if you're interested this is a great introduction to the region through a variety of perspectives

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It has been one of my favorite classes at Yale so far. If you are interested in understanding the role literature has in teaching histories, then this is the course for you. Professor Habchi did a fabulous job grounding us in postcolonial and diasporic theory in preparation for later discussions, but she also did such a great job pointing out how each novel did its own kind of theorization. I took a lot out of this course because I was able to read all of the novels (one a week) in their entirety. If you are not able to put in the time to do so, then I might discourage one from taking it only because it may not be as impactful. I LOVED this class!!!
